image.altText: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce speaks to the media during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Embattled Qantas boss Alan Joyce brings his retirement forward by two months after a horror period for the airline.

title.children: Alan Joyce abruptly departs Qantas after scandalous week and 'many ups and downs'

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: The judge overseeing a criminal trial into the deadly eruption of Whakaari White Island in 2019 dismisses charges against the three brothers who own the volcano, with proceedings set to continue over their company's involvement.

title.children: Judge in Whakaari White Island trial dismisses charges against brothers who own volcano

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has announced he will leave the airline tomorrow, bringing forward his planned retirement by two months. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas boss to leave tomorrow, bringing forward retirement by two months, local markets open lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank is expected to keep official interest rates on hold this afternoon at 4.1 per cent with the market predicting a 95 per cent chance of no change. AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina says the softening in inflation this year is in line with their expectations based on leading indicators of producer prices, commodity prices, manufacturing surveys, other business surveys, and the global economy. AMP expects inflation to slow further by the end of the year and they are predicting consumer inflation to come in at 4 per cent, near the RBA's forecast of 4.1 per cent. Consumer inflation eased to 4.9 per cent over the 12 months to July with housing and food the most significant price rises, offset by falling petrol prices. Ms Mousina sees little reason for an increase to rates at today's meeting and she thinks that rates are likely to remain unchanged for the rest of 2023, with a chance of rate cuts next year. Here's an interview I did with Diana Mousina last month on ABC News Channel after the unemployment rate rose from 3.5 per cent to 3.7 per cent in July.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMP predicts no more RBA interest rate rises

children.content: The
Reserve Bank
is expected to keep official interest rates on hold this afternoon at 4.1 per cent with the market predicting a 95 per cent chance of no change.
AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina

says the softening in inflation this year is in line with their expectations based on leading indicators of producer prices, commodity prices, manufacturing surveys, other business surveys, and the global economy.
AMP expects inflation to slow further by the end of the year and they are predicting consumer inflation to come in at 4 per cent, near the RBA's forecast of 4.1 per cent.
Consumer inflation eased to 4.9 per cent over the 12 months
to July with housing and food the most significant price rises, offset by falling petrol prices.
Ms Mousina sees little reason for an increase to rates at today's meeting and she thinks that rates are likely to remain unchanged for the rest of 2023, with a chance of rate cuts next year.
Here's an interview I did with Diana Mousina last month on ABC News Channel after the unemployment rate rose from 3.5 per cent to 3.7 per cent in July.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 index -0.5%) is trading lower as banks and commodity stocks pull down the market ahead of the RBA's latest decision on interest rates. The RBA is expected to stay on hold at 4.1 per cent. Most sectors are in the red with utilities, energy, and miners leading the losses. Mineral explorer Chalice Mining is taking a hit amid the fallout from its over optimistic assessment of commodity prices for its Julimar nickel-copper project. Stockbroker Jefferies has downgraded the explorer from hold to underperform saying that the "unattractive economics" of Juliimar are not yet fully factored into the share price. And this burn: "Assumed commodity prices for the valuation of the project did not represent the common practice of using consensus or lower to validate a project's robust economics." And Qantas (+0.4%) is higher after Alan Joyce stepped down. Top movers: BrainChip: +3.2% Iress: 2.4% Megaport: +1.6% Chalice Mining: -17.2% West African Resources: -4.7% Bellevue Gold: -4.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's the view of veteran aviation analyst Geoffrey Thomas about Alan Joyce's early departure as the boss of Qantas. Qantas announced this morning that Mr Joyce would bring forward his retirement by two months to help the company "accelerate its renewal" after a turbulent week for the airline. That includes a lawsuit by the competition regulator which alleges that Qantas sold tickets that had been cancelled. Mr Thomas told ABC News Channel that it was time for Mr Joyce to go. "He's the face of the airline." "And he's been a lightning rod for all the problems of the airline." "And so, with the latest ACCC allegations which have been brought into court, I think it was time for Alan to move on simply so that the focus could be taken away from him and let the airline deal with the issues it has to, without him being the focal point of all the criticism." Mr Thomas also thinks the Qantas board will take a look at Mr Joyce's multi million dollar salary and considering docking some of his bonuses. "These bonuses are eye-watering, particularly when the airline is having all these problems and passengers' flights have been disrupted, there's all sorts of allegations flying around." "I'm sure the board and the shareholders will look at the remuneration and they may make some adjustments to it." He says the new chief executive Vanessa Hudson faces alot of issues including updating the Qantas fleet. "Vanessa Hudson - who is now the CEO as of tomorrow - is the person who guided Qantas through the COVID pandemic, and she will be focused on shareholder value." "So the challenge for Vanessa going forward will be to maintain shareholder value while competing against airlines that either are government-owned or have far, far lower labour costs, like Indonesia." "And also, she has to oversee the biggest fleet overhaul Qantas has ever had." "That's going to be very challenging over the next three years." "So there's lots of obstacles for her."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Time for Alan to move on'

children.content: That's the view of veteran aviation analyst
Geoffrey Thomas
about Alan Joyce's early departure as the boss of Qantas.
Qantas announced this morning that Mr Joyce would bring forward his retirement by two months to help the company "accelerate its renewal" after a turbulent week for the airline.
That includes a lawsuit by the competition regulator which alleges that Qantas sold tickets that had been cancelled.
Mr Thomas told ABC News Channel that it was time for Mr Joyce to go.
"He's the face of the airline."
"And he's been a lightning rod for all the problems of the airline."

"And so, with the latest ACCC allegations which have been brought into court, I think it was time for Alan to move on simply so that the focus could be taken away from him and let the airline deal with the issues it has to, without him being the focal point of all the criticism."
Mr Thomas also thinks the Qantas board will take a look at Mr Joyce's multi million dollar salary and considering docking some of his bonuses.
"These bonuses are eye-watering, particularly when the airline is having all these problems and passengers' flights have been disrupted, there's all sorts of allegations flying around."
"I'm sure the board and the shareholders will look at the remuneration and they may make some adjustments to it."
He says the new chief executive Vanessa Hudson faces alot of issues including updating the Qantas fleet.
"Vanessa Hudson - who is now the CEO as of tomorrow - is the person who guided Qantas through the COVID pandemic, and she will be focused on shareholder value."

"So the challenge for Vanessa going forward will be to maintain shareholder value while competing against airlines that either are government-owned or have far, far lower labour costs, like Indonesia."
"And also, she has to oversee the biggest fleet overhaul Qantas has ever had."
"That's going to be very challenging over the next three years."
"So there's lots of obstacles for her."

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce will leave Qantas after 15 years with $125 million, while the airline's operations have suffered and its reputation has been trashed, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The never-ending spin that protected Alan Joyce and Qantas from reality has started to unravel

image.altText: A black and white image of murder victim Frank Foley.

items.synopsis: Human remains located by a fossicker last year have been linked to Frank Foley's close-living relatives, and police will conduct a forensic search at the site today.

title.children: Queensland police hope 'offenders can be brought to justice' after cold case breakthrough

image.altText: A woman lies back in a chair smiling, while someone injects her forehead with a syringe.

items.synopsis: Australia's medical regulator says it is cracking down on cosmetic procedures such as botox and fillers, but those living with the long-term impacts of botched procedures say the focus has come too late.

title.children: Cosmetic surgery crackdown now targeting fillers, botox and other procedures

image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: The Victorian Premier says the 12-month time frame set out by the Yoorrook Justice Commission to deliver urgent reform may be too ambitious for the government.

title.children: Daniel Andrews questions 'challenging' time frame for Yoorrook recommendations

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe, wearing earrings in the colours of the Aboriginal flag, sits in the senate, she looks up to the left

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe reveals her unlikely friendships with political adversaries, and says she was once approached by former Victorian premier Jeff Kennett to run for the Liberal Party.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe reveals her 'weird' and unlikely friendships in the Senate

image.altText: An aerial photo of a coal power plant surrounded by Australian bush.

items.synopsis: The NSW government will "engage with Origin Energy" on a proposed extension of the life of Australia's largest power plant.

title.children: NSW government moves to delay closure of Australia's largest coal-fired power station

image.altText: Prime Minister Kalsakau and Penny Wong sign a security agreement

items.synopsis: The new prime minister of Vanuatu flags he wants to rewrite a security pact his predecessor signed with Australia, saying parliament is unlikely to ratify the agreement in its current form.

title.children: Future of Australia's security pact with Vanuatu in doubt under new PM

image.altText: Dozens of photos, most arranged on top of each other, on a table

items.synopsis: Three decades after the legendary Queen frontman's death, more than 250 snaps from his personal albums are released publicly for the first time, painting a new picture of a world only his "nearest and dearest" knew until now.

title.children: Freddie Mercury's 'mythology busting' private photos revealed after 30 years

image.altText: a woman's hand holding a newborn baby's feet while in a maternity ward

items.synopsis: An upper house committee into the prevalence of birth trauma in New South Wales, expected to go for several months, received a record 4,000 submissions from the public.

title.children: 'Stop infantilising women': Birth trauma inquiry described as 'me too' moment for mothers in NSW on day one

image.altText: Man in white shirt

items.synopsis: Jurors have been told not be to be tempted to be television detectives when deliberating the fate of a man police allege gave a toddler a fatal dose of an antidepressant.

title.children: Jury hears man charged over toddler's antidepressant death 'not sharpest knife in the drawer', but not a killer

image.altText: A seven-month-old boy with scratches on his face and head.

items.synopsis: Seven-month-old Jack had been left alone, unsupervised, in a room when he was beaten by another child. His mother is now pursuing legal action and lawyers say their caseload of injuries sustained at childcare centres is increasing.

title.children: Injuries sustained at childcare centres are on the rise. Experts say there's one common factor

image.altText: A dark-haired boy standing on a boardwalk in bushland. His face is blurred and he cannot be identified.

items.synopsis: The boy's devastated family has been told he is likely to spend months in hospital. A 27-year-old man has been charged over the Sunshine Coast incident.

title.children: Boy, 12, on life support after being knocked off scooter by alleged drunk driver on Father's Day

image.altText: A red illuminated Westpac bank logo on a black wall with a blurred man walking past

items.synopsis: Westpac is facing civil court proceedings from ASIC, which alleges it failed to respond to hardship requests within the time required by law.

title.children: Cars and property seized after Westpac failed to respond to hardship requests, ASIC alleges

image.altText: An Australian Electoral Commission banner tied to a fence. It says "polling place" with opening hours 8am-6pm

items.synopsis: Rather than writing numbers, ticks or crosses, voters will have to either write the word "Yes" or "No" on their referendum ballot papers.

title.children: Voting on the Voice will be different than federal elections. Here's how

image.altText: Alex de Minaur plays a forehand volley during a match at the US Open.

items.synopsis: Former world number one Daniil Medvedev takes down Alex de Minaur in four sets to prevent the Australian 13th seed from making back-to-back quarterfinals in New York.

title.children: No more Australians in the US Open singles as Alex de Minaur dumped out by former champion

image.altText: Man in grey shirt and cap walks alongside red-haired woman

items.synopsis: Russian general Sergei Surovikin is seen in public for the first time since a mutiny by Wagner mercenaries, as Ukraine's military gains territory in its counteroffensive.

title.children: Russia's 'General Armageddon' reportedly seen for first time since Wagner mutiny

image.altText: India moon lander's view of the moon from space.

items.synopsis: The Indian Space Research Organisation will now focus on a sun research mission as the nation hopes to make its name in the field of space travel.

title.children: India puts moon rover to 'sleep' after successful mission

image.altText: A keyboard lights up in darkness

items.synopsis: Six Queensland men are charged with more than 100 child sex offences following extensive investigations connected to taskforce Argos detectives.

title.children: Six Queensland men charged with more than 100 child sex offences, 15,000 cases referred to child safety

image.altText: a woman in a white dress with her arms out standing on the sand

items.synopsis: They're integral to Australia's tourism and agriculture industries, but backpacker numbers dropped with travel restrictions during COVID-19.

title.children: Has Australia got its backpackers back? This data suggests so

image.altText: A lorry with a billboard of Julian Assange arrives at the front of a London court house.

items.synopsis: A multi-party delegation will visit Washington DC later this month to make the case for the US to drop extradition proceedings against Julian Assange, ahead of the prime minster's visit to the US in October.

title.children: Federal politicians to urge US to drop extradition of Julian Assange

image.altText: A close up of Kim Jong-un on the left and Vladimir Putin on the right.

items.synopsis: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is expected to travel to Russia within the month to meet with President Vladimir Putin, according to a US official, as the Kremlin tries to acquire military equipment for use in its war in Ukraine.

title.children: US says Kim Jong Un and Vladimir Putin planning to meet as Russia seeks arms for Ukraine war

image.altText: A long-haired man in a black wetsuit stands on the sand, holding a long yellow surfboard with a snake on the front of it.

items.synopsis: Shiva the surfing python has become an overnight sensation after footage of her gliding through Rainbow Bay went viral. Watch the video.

title.children: 'She's a natural': Meet the surfing snake turning heads in the waves at Snapper Rocks

image.altText: a composite image of two boys, seen from behind

items.synopsis: Brothers Kaleb and Jonathan*, then aged 19 and 17, were found in May 2020 after their father was discovered dead from a terminal illness at their Brisbane home.

title.children: Queensland government should compensate teens with autism found living in filth, royal commission finds

image.altText: julie inman grant speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: Stronger age verification processes are needed on sites used by children to help prevent them being coerced into making sexual abuse material, according to the eSafety commissioner.

title.children: Children easily bypassing age verification online, eSafety commissioner says

image.altText: People dressed all in black hold up placards with Korean text.

items.synopsis: Tens of thousands of South Korean teachers rally to demand better protection of their rights and spotlight what they called widespread harassment by overbearing parents.

title.children: South Korean teachers protest over student and parent behaviour after another colleague's apparent suicide

image.altText: A still taken from the All Star music video by the American rock band Smash Mouth.

items.synopsis: The All Star singer died in hospice care after entering the final stages of liver failure.

title.children: Smash Mouth's long-time frontman Steve Harwell dies from liver failure at 56

image.altText: Two people in red hi-vis swim through flood waters next to a bridge.

items.synopsis: One of the flood's victims was a man who was trapped in a lift that filled up with water, as record rainfall inundated Central Spain.

title.children: At least three people are dead and more are missing in Spanish floods
